          • Vectorized (universal) functions
            • Characterizing arrays
              • max: Return the maximum along a given axis.
              • argmax: Return indices of the maximum values along the given axis.
              • min: Return the minimum along a given axis.
              • argmin: Return indices of the minimum values along the given axis of a.
              • ptp: Peak-to-peak (maximum - minimum) value along a given axis.
              • trace: Return the sum along diagonals of the array.
              • mean: Returns the average of the array elements along given axis.
              • var: Returns the variance of the array elements, along given axis.
              • std: Returns the standard deviation of the array elements along given axis.
              • all: Returns True if all elements evaluate to True.
              • any: Returns True if any of the elements of a evaluate to True.
            • Sums, products, differences within array
              • prod: Product of array elements over a given axis
              • sum: Sum of array elements over a given axis
              • nansum: Sum of array elements over a given axis treating NaNs as zero
              • cumprod: Cumulative product of elements along a given axis
              • cumsum: Cumulative sum of the elements along a given axis
              • diff: Calculate the n-th order discrete difference along given axis
              • ediff1d: Differences between consecutive elements of an array
              • gradient: Gradient of an N-dimensional array
              • trapz: Integrate along the given axis using the composite trapezoidal rule
              • convolve: Discrete, linear convolution of two one-dimensional sequences
              • interp: One-dimensional linear interpolation
            • Logarithms and exponentials
              • logaddexp: Logarithm of the sum of exponentiations of the inputs
              • logaddexp2: Logarithm of the sum of exponentiations of the inputs in base-2
              • power: First array elements raised to powers from second array, element-wise
              • power: First array elements raised to powers from second array, element-wise with automatic domain
              • exp: Calculate the exponential of all elements in the input array
              • exp2: Calculate 2𝑝2p for all 𝑝p in the input array
              • log: Natural logarithm, element-wise
              • log: Natural logarithm, element-wise with automatic domain
              • log2: Base-2 logarithm of 𝑥x
              • log2: Base-2 logarithm of 𝑥x with automatic domain
              • log10: Return the base 10 logarithm of the input array, element-wise
              • log10: Return the base 10 logarithm of the input array, element-wise with automatic domain
              • logn: Return the base 𝑛n logarithm of the input array, element-wise with automatic domain
              • expm1: Calculate exp(𝑥)−1exp⁡(x)−1 for all elements in the array
              • log1p: Calculate log(1+𝑥)log⁡(1+x) for all elements in the array
              • sqrt: Return the positive square-root of an array, element-wise
              • sqrt: Return the positive square-root of an array, element-wise with automatic domain
              • square: Return the element-wise square of the input
              • reciprocal: Return the reciprocal of the argument, element-wise
            • Trigonometric and hyperbolic functions
              • sin: Trigonometric sine, element-wise
              • cos: Cosine element-wise
              • tan: Compute tangent element-wise
              • arcsin: Trigonometric inverse sine, element-wise
              • arcsin: Trigonometric inverse sine, element-wise with automatic domain
              • arccos: Trigonometric inverse cosine, element-wise
              • arccos: Trigonometric inverse cosine, element-wise with automatic domain
              • arctan: Trigonometric inverse tangent, element-wise
              • arctan2: Element-wise arc tangent of 𝑥1/𝑥2x1/x2 choosing the quadrant correctly
              • hypot: Given the “legs” of a right triangle, return its hypotenuse
              • sinh: Hyperbolic sine, element-wise
              • cosh: Hyperbolic cosine, element-wise
              • tanh: Compute hyperbolic tangent element-wise
              • arcsinh: Inverse hyperbolic sine element-wise
              • arccosh: Inverse hyperbolic cosine, element-wise
              • arctanh: Inverse hyperbolic tangent, element-wise
              • arctanh: Inverse hyperbolic tangent, element-wise with automatic domain
              • deg2rad: Convert angles from degrees to radians
              • rad2deg: Convert angles from radians to degrees
              • unwrap: Unwrap radian phase by changing jumps greater than 𝜋π to their 2𝜋2π complement
            • Complex numbers
              • real: Real part of the elements of the array
              • imag: Imaginary part of the elements of the array
              • conj: Complex conjugate, element-wise
              • angle: Angle of the complex argument
              • unwrap: Unwrap radian phase by changing jumps greater than 𝜋π to their 2𝜋2π complement
            • Rounding and clipping
              • around: Evenly round to the given number of decimals
              • rint: Round elements of the array to the nearest integer
              • fix: Round to nearest integer towards zero
              • floor: Floor of the input, element-wise
              • ceil: Ceiling of the input, element-wise
              • trunc: Truncated value of the input, element-wise
              • clip: Clip (limit) the values in an array
              • nan_to_num: Replace NaNs with zero and inf with finite numbers
              • real_if_close: Truncate complex parts if within `tol` times machine epsilon of zero
            • Float functions
              • isreal: Returns a bool array, where True if input element is real
              • iscomplex: Returns a bool array, where True if input element is complex
              • isfinite: Test element-wise for finiteness (not infinity and not NaN)
              • isinf: Test element-wise for positive or negative infinity
              • isnan: Test element-wise for NaN and return result as a boolean array
              • signbit: Returns element-wise True where signbit is set (less than zero)
              • copysign: Change the sign of 𝑥1x1 to that of 𝑥2x2, element-wise
              • nextafter: Return the next floating-point value after 𝑥1x1 towards 𝑥2x2, element-wise
              • modf: Return the fractional and integral parts of an array, element-wise
              • ldexp: Returns 𝑥12𝑥2x12x2, element-wise
              • frexp: Decompose the elements of 𝑥x into mantissa and twos exponent
              • fmod: Return the element-wise remainder of division
              • floor: Return the floor of the input, element-wise
              • ceil: Return the ceiling of the input, element-wise
              • trunc: Return the truncated value of the input, element-wise
            • Bit-twiddling functions
              • bitwise_and: Compute the bit-wise AND of two arrays element-wise
              • bitwise_or: Compute the bit-wise OR of two arrays element-wise
              • bitwise_xor: Compute the bit-wise XOR of two arrays element-wise
              • invert: Compute bit-wise inversion, or bit-wise NOT, element-wise
              • left_shift: Shift the bits of an integer to the left
              • right_shift: Shift the bits of an integer to the right
            • Special functions (see scipy.special)
              • i0: Modified Bessel function of the first kind, order 0
              • sinc: Return the sinc function
            • Arithmetic
              • add: Add arguments element-wise
              • subtract: Subtract arguments, element-wise
              • multiply: Multiply arguments element-wise
              • divide: Divide arguments element-wise
              • true_divide: Returns a true division of the inputs, element-wise
              • floor_divide: Return the largest integer smaller or equal to the division of the inputs
              • negative: Numerical negative, element-wise
              • remainder: Return element-wise remainder of integer division
              • mod: Return element-wise remainder of integer division
              • fmod: Return element-wise remainder of float division
              • modf: Return the fractional and integral parts of an array, element-wise
              • absolute: Calculate the absolute value element-wise
              • rint: Round elements of the array to the nearest integer
              • sign: Returns an element-wise indication of the sign of a number
              • conj: Return the complex conjugate, element-wise
              • sqrt: Return the positive square-root of an array, element-wise
              • sqrt: Return the positive square-root of an array, element-wise with automatic domain
              • square: Return the element-wise square of the input
              • reciprocal: Return the reciprocal of the argument, element-wise
            • Matrix and vector products
              • tensordot: Tensor dot product over last 𝑛n axes of a and first 𝑛n of b
              • tensordot: Tensor dot product over given pairs of axes
              • einsum: Evaluate Einstein summation convention on operands
              • inner: Inner product, summing over last two axes
              • outer: Compute outer product of two vectors (automatically flattened)
              • kron: Kronecker product of arrays
              • vdot: Dot product of two complex vectors, conjugating the first
              • dot: Dot product of two arrays over last and second-to-last dimensions, respectively
              • cross: Cross product of two (arrays of) vectors
            • Comparisons between two arrays
              • greater: Return the truth value of (𝑥1>𝑥2)(x1>x2) element-wise
              • greater_equal: Return the truth value of (𝑥1≥𝑥2)(x1≥x2) element-wise
              • less: Return the truth value of (𝑥1<𝑥2)(x1<x2) element-wise
              • less_equal: Return the truth value of (𝑥1≤𝑥2)(x1≤x2) element-wise
              • not_equal: Return (𝑥1!=𝑥2)(x1!=x2) element-wise
              • equal: Return (𝑥1==𝑥2)(x1==x2) element-wise
              • logical_and: Compute the truth value of 𝑥1x1 AND 𝑥2x2 element-wise
              • logical_or: Compute the truth value of 𝑥1x1 OR 𝑥2x2 element-wise
              • logical_xor: Compute the truth value of 𝑥1x1 XOR 𝑥2x2, element-wise
              • logical_not: Compute the truth value of NOT 𝑥x element-wise
              • maximum: Element-wise maximum of array elements
              • minimum: Element-wise minimum of array elements

                  • Bessel Functions
                    • Bessel Functions
                      • jv: Bessel function of the first kind of real order 𝑣v, 𝐽𝑣(𝑧)Jv(z)
                      • jve: Exponentially scaled Bessel function of the first kind of order 𝑣v, 𝐽𝑣(𝑧)𝑒−|ℑ𝑧|Jv(z)e−|ℑz|
                      • yn: Bessel function of the second kind of integer order 𝑛n, 𝑌𝑛(𝑥)Yn(x)
                      • yv: Bessel function of the second kind of real order 𝑣v, 𝑌𝑣(𝑧)Yv(z)
                      • yve: Exponentially scaled Bessel function of the second kind of real order, 𝑌𝑣(𝑧)𝑒−|ℑ𝑧|Yv(z)e−|ℑz|
                      • kn: Modified Bessel function of the second kind of integer order 𝑛n, 𝐾𝑛(𝑥)Kn(x)
                      • kv: Modified Bessel function of the second kind of real order 𝑣v, 𝐾𝑣(𝑧)Kv(z)
                      • kve: Exponentially scaled modified Bessel function of the second kind, 𝐾𝑣(𝑧)𝑒𝑧Kv(z)ez
                      • iv: Modified Bessel function of the first kind of real order 𝑣v, 𝐼𝑣(𝑧)Iv(z)
                      • ive: Exponentially scaled modified Bessel function of the first kind of real order 𝑣v, 𝐼𝑣(𝑧)𝑒−|ℜ𝑧|Iv(z)e−|ℜz|
                      • hankel1: Hankel function of the first kind, 𝐻(1)𝑣(𝑧)Hv(1)(z)
                      • hankel1e: Exponentially scaled Hankel function of the first kind, 𝐻(1)𝑣(𝑧)𝑒−𝑖𝑧Hv(1)(z)e−iz
                      • hankel2: Hankel function of the second kind, 𝐻(2)𝑣(𝑧)Hv(2)(z)
                      • hankel2e: Exponentially scaled Hankel function of the second kind, 𝐻(2)𝑣(𝑧)𝑒𝑖𝑧Hv(2)(z)eiz
                      • lmbda: Compute sequence of lambda functions with arbitrary order 𝑣v and their derivatives
                    • Zeros of Bessel Functions
                      • jnjnp_zeros: Compute nt (<=1200) zeros of the Bessel functions 𝐽𝑛Jn and 𝐽′𝑛Jn′ and arange them in order of their magnitudes
                      • jnyn_zeros: Compute nt zeros of the Bessel functions 𝐽𝑛(𝑥)Jn(x), 𝐽′𝑛(𝑥)Jn′(x), 𝑌𝑛(𝑥)Yn(x), and 𝑌′𝑛(𝑥)Yn′(x), respectively
                      • jn_zeros: Compute nt zeros of the Bessel function 𝐽𝑛(𝑥)Jn(x)
                      • jnp_zeros: Compute nt zeros of the Bessel function 𝐽′𝑛(𝑥)Jn′(x)
                      • yn_zeros: Compute nt zeros of the Bessel function 𝑌𝑛(𝑥)Yn(x)
                      • ynp_zeros: Compute nt zeros of the Bessel function 𝑌′𝑛(𝑥)Yn′(x)
                      • y0_zeros: Returns nt (complex or real) zeros of 𝑌0(𝑧)Y0(z), 𝑧0z0, and the value of 𝑌′0(𝑧0)=−𝑌1(𝑧0)Y0′(z0)=−Y1(z0) at each zero
                      • y1_zeros: Returns nt (complex or real) zeros of 𝑌1(𝑧)Y1(z), 𝑧1z1, and the value of 𝑌′1(𝑧1)=𝑌0(𝑧1)Y1′(z1)=Y0(z1) at each zero
                      • y1p_zeros: Returns nt (complex or real) zeros of 𝑌′1(𝑧)Y1′(z), 𝑧′1z1′, and the value of 𝑌1(𝑧′1)Y1(z1′) at each zero
                    • Faster versions of common Bessel Functions
                      • j0: Bessel function the first kind of order 0, 𝐽0(𝑥)J0(x)
                      • j1: Bessel function of the first kind of order 1, 𝐽1(𝑥)J1(x)
                      • y0: Bessel function of the second kind of order 0, 𝑌0(𝑥)Y0(x)
                      • y1: Bessel function of the second kind of order 1, 𝑌1(𝑥)Y1(x)

                      • i0e: Exponentially scaled modified Bessel function of order 0, 𝐼0(𝑥)𝑒−|𝑥|I0(x)e−|x|
                      • i1: Modified Bessel function of order 1, 𝐼1(𝑥)I1(x)

                    • Integrals of Bessel Functions

                      • iti0k0: Integrals of modified Bessel functions of order 0: ∫𝑥0𝐼0(𝑡)𝑑𝑡∫0xI0(t)dt, ∫𝑥0𝐾0(𝑡)𝑑𝑡∫0xK0(t)dt
                      • it2i0k0: Integrals related to modified Bessel functions of order 0: ∫𝑥0𝐼0(𝑡)−1𝑡𝑑𝑡∫0xI0(t)−1tdt, ∫∞𝑥𝐾0(𝑡)𝑡𝑑𝑡∫x∞K0(t)tdt
                      • besselpoly: Weighted integral of a Bessel function, ∫10𝑥𝜆𝐽𝜈(2𝑎𝑥)𝑑𝑥∫01xλJν(2ax)dx

            # ARMAX Model Implementation with NumPy and SciPy
            ​

            ARMAX Model Implementation with NumPy and SciPy¶

            xxxxxxxxxx
             
            The code provided is an implementation of the ARMAX model, which is an extension of the ARMA model that includes exogenous variables. The ARMAX model combines autoregressive (AR) terms, moving average (MA) terms, and exogenous variables. The general form of an ARMAX(p, q) model can be expressed as:
            ​
            $$y_t = c + \varphi_1y_{t-1} + \cdots + \varphi_py_{t-p} + \theta_1e_{t-1} + \cdots + \theta_qe_{t-q} + \beta_1x_{1,t} + \cdots + \beta_kx_{k,t} + e_t$$
            ​
            where:
            - $y_t$ is the value of the time series at time t
            - $c$ is a constant term
            - $\varphi_i$ are the AR coefficients for i = 1, ..., p
            - $\theta_j$ are the MA coefficients for j = 1, ..., q
            - $e_t$ is the error term (residual) at time t
            - $x_{i,t}$ are the exogenous variables at time t
            - $\beta_i$ are the coefficients for the exogenous variables
            - $p$ is the order of the autoregressive part (AR)
            - $q$ is the order of the moving average part (MA)
            ​
            Now, let's break down the math behind each part of the code:
            ​
            1. **armax_residuals function:**
            ​
            The purpose of this function is to compute the residuals of the ARMAX model. Residuals are the differences between the observed values and the predicted values. The calculation is performed using the AR, MA, and exogenous coefficients:
            ​
            - `ar_sum`: Calculates the sum of the autoregressive terms for the current time step.
            - `ma_sum`: Calculates the sum of the moving average terms for the current time step.
            - `exog_sum`: Calculates the sum of the exogenous terms for the current time step.
            ​
            The residual at time `t` is calculated as:
            ​
            $$\text{residuals}[t] = \text{data}[t] - \text{ar_sum} - \text{ma_sum} - \text{exog_sum}$$
            ​
            2. **armax_predict function:**
            ​
            This function predicts future values using the ARMAX model. The calculation is performed in a similar manner as in the `armax_residuals` function:
            ​
            - `ar_sum`: Calculates the sum of the autoregressive terms for the current time step.
            - `ma_sum`: Calculates the sum of the moving average terms for the current time step.
            - `exog_sum`: Calculates the sum of the exogenous terms for the current time step.
            ​
            The prediction at time `t` is calculated as:
            ​
            $$\text{prediction} = \text{ar_sum} + \text{ma_sum} + \text{exog_sum}$$
            ​
            3. **fit_armax function:**
            ​
            This function estimates the AR, MA, and exogenous coefficients using the given data, exogenous variables, and the orders of the AR and MA components. It does this by minimizing the sum of squared residuals using the `minimize` function from the `scipy.optimize` library.
            ​
            The objective function to be minimized is the sum of squared residuals:
            ​
            $$\text{objective} = \sum (\text{armax_residuals}(\text{params}, \text{data}, \text{exog}, p, q))^2$$
            ​
            The `minimize` function is used to find the optimal parameters that minimize the objective function:
            ​
            $$\text{result} = \text{minimize}(\lambda \text{params}: \text{objective}, \text{init_params}, \text{method}='\text{L-BFGS-B}')$$
            ​
            The `result.x` attribute of the `minimize` function's output contains the optimal AR, MA, and exogenous coefficients.
            ​
            ​

            The code provided is an implementation of the ARMAX model, which is an extension of the ARMA model that includes exogenous variables. The ARMAX model combines autoregressive (AR) terms, moving average (MA) terms, and exogenous variables. The general form of an ARMAX(p, q) model can be expressed as:

            𝑦𝑡=𝑐+𝜑1𝑦𝑡−1+⋯+𝜑𝑝𝑦𝑡−𝑝+𝜃1𝑒𝑡−1+⋯+𝜃𝑞𝑒𝑡−𝑞+𝛽1𝑥1,𝑡+⋯+𝛽𝑘𝑥𝑘,𝑡+𝑒𝑡(1)(1)yt=c+φ1yt−1+⋯+φpyt−p+θ1et−1+⋯+θqet−q+β1x1,t+⋯+βkxk,t+et

            where:

            • 𝑦𝑡yt is the value of the time series at time t
            • 𝑐c is a constant term
            • 𝜑𝑖φi are the AR coefficients for i = 1, ..., p
            • 𝜃𝑗θj are the MA coefficients for j = 1, ..., q
            • 𝑒𝑡et is the error term (residual) at time t
            • 𝑥𝑖,𝑡xi,t are the exogenous variables at time t
            • 𝛽𝑖βi are the coefficients for the exogenous variables
            • 𝑝p is the order of the autoregressive part (AR)
            • 𝑞q is the order of the moving average part (MA)

            Now, let's break down the math behind each part of the code:

            1. armax_residuals function:

            The purpose of this function is to compute the residuals of the ARMAX model. Residuals are the differences between the observed values and the predicted values. The calculation is performed using the AR, MA, and exogenous coefficients:

            • ar_sum: Calculates the sum of the autoregressive terms for the current time step.
            • ma_sum: Calculates the sum of the moving average terms for the current time step.
            • exog_sum: Calculates the sum of the exogenous terms for the current time step.

            The residual at time t is calculated as:

            residuals[𝑡]=data[𝑡]−ar_sum−ma_sum−exog_sum(2)(2)residuals[t]=data[t]−ar_sum−ma_sum−exog_sum

            1. armax_predict function:

            This function predicts future values using the ARMAX model. The calculation is performed in a similar manner as in the armax_residuals function:

            • ar_sum: Calculates the sum of the autoregressive terms for the current time step.
            • ma_sum: Calculates the sum of the moving average terms for the current time step.
            • exog_sum: Calculates the sum of the exogenous terms for the current time step.

            The prediction at time t is calculated as:

            prediction=ar_sum+ma_sum+exog_sum(3)(3)prediction=ar_sum+ma_sum+exog_sum

            1. fit_armax function:

            This function estimates the AR, MA, and exogenous coefficients using the given data, exogenous variables, and the orders of the AR and MA components. It does this by minimizing the sum of squared residuals using the minimize function from the scipy.optimize library.

            The objective function to be minimized is the sum of squared residuals:

            objective=∑(armax_residuals(params,data,exog,𝑝,𝑞))2(4)(4)objective=∑(armax_residuals(params,data,exog,p,q))2

            The minimize function is used to find the optimal parameters that minimize the objective function:

            result=minimize(𝜆params:objective,init_params,method=′L-BFGS-B′)(5)(5)result=minimize(λparams:objective,init_params,method=′L-BFGS-B′)

            The result.x attribute of the minimize function's output contains the optimal AR, MA, and exogenous coefficients.

            In [5]:

            # Import the NumPy library, It's a fundamental library for scientific computing in Python.
            import numpy as np
            ​
            # Import the minimize function from the scipy.optimize module. This function is used for
            # optimization tasks, such as finding the minimum value of a function or fitting parameters
            # to a model. In this case, it will be used to estimate the AR, MA, and exogenous coefficients
            # for the ARMAX model by minimizing the sum of squared residuals.
            ​
            from scipy.optimize import minimize
            ​
            . . .
            In [3]:

            ​
            ​
            def armax_residuals(params, data, exog, p, q):
                # Separate AR, MA, and exogenous coefficients from the input params array
                ar_params = params[:p]
                ma_params = params[p:p+q]
                exog_params = params[p+q:]
            ​
                # Get the length of the data and initialize an array of zeros for residuals
                n = len(data)
                residuals = np.zeros(n)
            ​
                # Loop through each data point
                for t in range(n):
                    # Calculate the sum of autoregressive terms, if we have enough history
                    ar_sum = np.sum(ar_params * data[t-p:t][::-1]) if t >= p else 0
                    
                    # Calculate the sum of moving average terms, if we have enough history
                    ma_sum = np.sum(ma_params * residuals[t-q:t][::-1]) if t >= q else 0
                    
                    # Calculate the sum of exogenous terms using the dot product
                    exog_sum = np.dot(exog_params, exog[t])
                    
                    # Compute the residual at time t
                    residuals[t] = data[t] - ar_sum - ma_sum - exog_sum
            ​
                # Return the array of residuals
                return residuals
            ​
            ​
            def armax_predict(params, data, exog, p, q, steps):
                # Separate AR, MA, and exogenous coefficients from the input params array
                ar_params = params[:p]
                ma_params = params[p:p+q]
                exog_params = params[p+q:]
            ​
                # Get the length of the data
                n = len(data)
                
                # Create a list of historical data points and residuals
                history = list(data)
                residuals = list(armax_residuals(params, data, exog, p, q))
                
                # Initialize an empty list to store the predictions
                predictions = []
            ​
                # Loop through the number of steps to predict
                for t in range(steps):
                    # Calculate the sum of autoregressive terms using the historical data
                    ar_sum = np.sum(ar_params * history[-p:][::-1]) if len(history) >= p else 0
                    
                    # Calculate the sum of moving average terms using the residuals
                    ma_sum = np.sum(ma_params * residuals[-q:][::-1]) if len(residuals) >= q else 0
                    
                    # Calculate the sum of exogenous terms using the dot product
                    exog_sum = np.dot(exog_params, exog[n+t]) if n+t < len(exog) else 0
                    
                    # Compute the prediction at the current time step
                    prediction = ar_sum + ma_sum + exog_sum
                    
                    # Append the prediction to the list of predictions
                    predictions.append(prediction)
            ​
                    # Update the history and residuals with the new prediction
                    history.append(prediction)
                    residuals.append(0)  # Assuming zero residual for prediction
            ​
                # Return the list of predictions
                return predictions
            ​
            ​
            def fit_armax(data, exog, p, q):
                # Initialize random AR, MA, and exogenous coefficients as the starting point for optimization
                init_params = np.random.normal(size=p+q+len(exog[0]))
            ​
                # Define the objective function for the optimization process:
                # The sum of squared residuals from the armax_residuals function
                objective = lambda params: np.sum(np.square(armax_residuals(params, data, exog, p, q)))
            ​
                # Optimize the objective function using the minimize function from scipy.optimize,
                # which finds the AR, MA, and exogenous coefficients that minimize the sum of squared residuals
                result = minimize(
                    objective,         # The objective function to minimize
                    init_params,       # The initial guess for the parameters
                    method='L-BFGS-B', # The optimization algorithm (Limited-memory Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno)
                )
            ​
                # Return the optimal AR, MA, and exogenous coefficients found by the optimization process
                return result.x
            ​

            # Generate synthetic data 
            np.random.seed(42)
            n = 100
            # Generate signal
            data = np.random.normal(size=n)
            # Generate exogenous variables
            exog = np.random.normal(size=(n, 1)) 
            ​
            # Fit the ARMAX model
            p, q = 2, 2  # Specify the order of the AR and MA components
            params = fit_armax(data, exog, p, q)
            print("ARMAX parameters:", params)
            ​
            # Make predictions
            steps = 3  # Number of steps to predict
            predictions = armax_predict(params, data, exog, p, q, steps)
            # Print predictions
            print("Predictions:", predictions)
